p: The citizens themselves might take measures to protect values at risk from climate change, should the society fail to protect them. The preparedness to take measures to adapt has been shown to depend on the decision-making agents' perception of risk, e.g. [ 5]. Based on a belief-desire model [ 6– 7] driving adaptation, recent studies show that the responses to two questions about the individual, on her or his strength of belief in local effects of climate change and in having experienced the effects of climate change, provide an almost complete explanation to adaptation of forest management to the effects of climate change among private forest owners [ 8– 9]. How strongly an individual believes in the local effects of climate change and in having experienced the effects of climate change are thus important determinants of his or her adaptive measures and hence affects his or her vulnerability to climate change as well.
